div1.p: Lampson solicits information about Gorgas for an upcoming book on the conquest of yellow fever.

div1.head: Memorandum from Robin Lampson, December 14, 1937
div1.p: TO THOSE INTERESTED IN THE LATE DR. WILLIAM CRAWFORD GORGAS:n

I am writing a book based on Dr. Gorgas's life, especially his
conquest of yellow fever through mosquito abatement, to be
called “Death Loses a Pair of Wings.”

Charles Scribner's Sons, New York, who published my first his-
torical novel, “Laughter Out of the Ground,” have contracted to
publish my Gorgas book as soon as the manuscript is ready. (I
inclose--for your information, not as an advertisement--one of
the publisher's announcements of the first book.)

I have already received much helpful information from Gorgas's
daughter, Mrs. W. D. Wrightson, his sister, Miss Mary G. Gorgas,
as well as from others associated with him in his great work,
such as Dr. Joseph A. LePrince. Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear and Mrs.
Samuel T. Darling are also cooperating.

Naturally, I am already familiar with the general outlines of
Gorgas's life--the important incidents of historical record.
But, except for a few items, I still lack the little more-or-
less homely personal anecdotes such as make the characters of
a novel come to life.

If you, or anyone else within your knowledge, can supply me
with some of these little humanizing and vivifying items about
Gorgas--what he did or said on such-and-such occasion--I, and
my readers as well, I believe, will be permanently indebted to
you. And of course, any contribution of material to the book
will be gratefully acknowledged in the foreword.

I think General Gorgas's story is one of the proudest chapters
in American and recent history. This truly great American de-
serves to be more “in the hearts of his countrymen”--in their
textbooks and on their tongues--than he now is. I sincerely
hope you will cooperate to make my book, “Death Loses a Pair
of Wings,” a fine and comprehensive memorial to that great man.
